awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  A continuum model for simultaneous prediction of granular flow and size-segregation in general geometries
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET - 1552556
PI: Henann, David L.

The goal of this CAREER project is to develop a theoretical model that describes the behavior of flowing granular materials. Granular materials are ubiquitous - they include naturally-occurring materials such as sand, soil, and snow, as well as industrial and agricultural materials such as pharmaceutical pills and capsules, food grains, and catalyst particles. Predicting the behavior of these materials during flow poses special challenges, especially when the granular material consists of particles of different sizes. In this case, the flow causes the particles to segregate according to size, which, in turn, affects the flow of the material as a whole. The theory developed in this project will use nonlocal modeling to describe a representative granular material consisting of particles of two different sizes - called bidisperse. The resulting model will predict the flow behavior of this bidisperse system in several prototype flow geometries, and the results will be compared with corresponding experiments conducted as part of the project. A variety of educational activities are also planned, including the development of new modules illustrating computational methods in solid mechanics. The project will enlist undergraduates to participate in the research, and workshops will be conducted to disseminate results and engage broad technical communities.
 
A predictive continuum theory, based on nonlocal modeling, will be developed that simultaneously predicts size segregation and flow in bidisperse dense granular systems composed of spherical particles. Preliminary tests have demonstrated that this approach produces a model that can predict coupled flow fields and segregation patterns. A systematic set of discrete-element calculations will be performed to isolate shear-strain-rate-driven and gravity-driven mechanisms of segregation, which will clarify the two-way coupling between flow and segregation. The model will then be generalized to three-dimensional flows using a continuum thermomechanics approach, and a finite-element implementation of the non-local, coupled theory will be developed. Predictions of the model will be validated by comparing with experiments of bidisperse granular systems in representative flow configurations.

por.por_cntn:
Granular materials are ubiquitous in nature as well as in industrial applications in forms such as sand, gravel, food grains, and industrial powders. However, granular materials display several mechanical behaviors that remain challenging to model at the continuum scale, e.g., nonlocal effects, secondary rheology, shear banding, and size segregation in flowing granular mixtures. This award addressed several problems related to continuum modeling and numerical simulation of monodisperse and bidisperse dense granular systems, which are highlighted below.

Contributions to modeling of monodisperse granular systems:

Local rheological constitutive equations for dense granular materials cannot capture many aspects of dense granular flow. This award contributed to the development and validation of a nonlocal continuum modeling approach, called the Nonlocal Granular Fluidity (NGF) model. Several specific contributions are listed below.

Nonlocal effects are evident in dense granular heap flows (e.g., avalanches and landslides in nature), which consist of a rapid flow regime localized near the free surface and a creeping flow region deep beneath the surface. We applied the NGF model to a representative steady, dense granular heap flow setup and successfully captured the salient features of both regions, which existing, local continuum models have not been able to simultaneously predict.

The flow threshold of dense granular materials exhibits a size effect that cannot be captured by conventional local, stress-based criteria. Using Discrete Element Method (DEM) calculations, we explored the configurational generality of the size-dependence of the flow threshold (i.e., additional strengthening with smaller system size) and showed that the NGF model is capable of quantitatively capturing this effect.

Experiments have shown that shear deformation in one region of a granular medium fluidizes its entirety, erasing the yield condition everywhere and enabling slow creep deformation to occur when an external force is applied to a probe in the nominally static regions of the material. We applied the NGF model to simulate dense flow in a split-bottom cell with a vane-shape intruder and showed that our simulations quantitatively captured the experimentally-observed phenomena.

Local rheological constitutive equations for steady, dense granular flow have been shown to display a linear instability under short wavelength perturbations, i.e., Hadamard instability. We demonstrated that the NGF model, which involves higher-order flow gradients, successfully regularizes the Hadamard instability. By applying the NGF model in fully nonlinear, finite-element simulations, we also showed that the NGF model is capable of predicting diffuse shear localization without mesh-dependence.

Contributions to modeling of bidisperse granular systems:

Dense granular systems consisting of particles of disparate sizes segregate based on size during flow, resulting in complex, coupled segregation and flow patterns. This award developed a continuum model capable of predicting both the flow fields and the segregation dynamics, based solely on the geometry of the flow configuration, applied loads, and boundary/initial conditions. Specific contributions are highlighted below.

We isolated and studied the two driving forces of size-segregation (pressure-gradients and shear-strain-rate-gradients) in dense flows of bidisperse particles, using DEM simulations. A phenomenological continuum model for size-segregation in dense flows of bidisperse particles was then developed, involving (1) a diffusion flux, (2) a shear-strain-rate-gradient-driven segregation flux, and (3) a pressure-gradient-driven segregation flux.

By coupling the model for size-segregation with an adapted NGF model for bidisperse granular materials, we established that the continuum model is capable of quantitatively predicting both flow fields and segregation dynamics simultaneously, which no previous continuum model has achieved. The continuum model was tested by comparing model predictions against DEM simulation results of dense bidisperse flow in a variety of geometries (e.g., vertical chute flow, inclined plane flow, and planar shear flow with gravity), and the model was shown to be capable of capturing the different flow and segregation fields that arise as the configuration and various input parameters are changed.

We developed a finite-element-based numerical approach for the coupled continuum model for flow and size-segregation in bidisperse granular mixtures, which is capable of predicting flow fields and size-segregation dynamics simultaneously for general 3D problems. The numerical simulation capability was used to validate the coupled model against DEM data for annular shear flow with gravity.

Broader impacts: Owing to the many instances of granular flow in industry and geophysics, the continuum model developed in this award provides a key tool for predicting size-segregation and flow in general circumstances, enabling a path toward improved and more efficient designs in a variety of engineering applications. The award provided the opportunity for three PhD students and three undergraduate students to perform in-depth scientific research. The award also led to the development of new course modules illustrating computational methods in solid mechanics and the organization of workshops and symposia that disseminated research results and engaged broad technical communities.
